The Inbetweeners Movie

This summer we join the nation's favourite incompetent teenagers on their quest to Malia for "sex, booze, tits, sex, fanny, minge . . . sex, tits, booze and . . . sex".

Rise of the Planet of the Apes

What has consistently made the <em>Planet of the Apes</em> films so fascinating is of course the inclusion of apes. Not necessarily because they scream and shout and make other amusing guttural noises; or because they wield a supra-human strength and are capable of smashing shit up, but more due to the fact that they so closely resemble us human beings.

Arrietty

<em>Arrietty</em> doesn't represent the first time that the much loved Studio Ghibli has dabbled in the art of adaptation. <em>Howl's Moving Castle</em>, and <em>Ponyo</em> both finding their original source material in the work of established children's authors.

The Riots: Fashion goes from riches to rags

The riots have shown no mercy to both high street shops and high fashion stores alike. Although there is no question that the riots have affected a range of businesses across the retail spectrum it is evident that larger stores such as Debenhams will be able to recover in time whereas smaller independent stores may have to close their doors forever

Last Night

The new Keira Knightley film verges on being similar to Closer staring Jude Law, but is more concise in its delivery. Paris Bennett lifts the lid on this unfortunately overlooked 90-minute film. Rating: ****

Edinburgh Fringe '11: Where to eat

By James Bithell

Whether you're performing or watching, the Fringe is a big one, and cafes will feel like a godsend in between shows. Mia de Graaf gives you her pick of pizza places, chocolate soup cafes, and hog roast rolls in Edinburgh this year (Thumbnail credit A Kilimanjaro coffee. Image: alixanaeuphoria via Flickr)

Lucian Freud dies aged 88

Celebrated German-British artist Lucian Freud has died aged 88 in his London home (Thumbnail credit Lucian Freud: Self Portrait, Reflection [2002]. Image: freeparking via Flickr)

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2

It is the end of Harry Potter. This film makes it go out with a bang, a smile, a tear. Yates has seen us through the end admirably well, even though he hasn't always tapped into the rich story in his hands with bold depth

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

The Importance of Being Earnest

<em>The Importance of Being Earnest</em> is a fine production to end the year on; it should be recommended to those who have not seen the play before, yet it still offers something to those already familiar with the script

Not seen. Not heard.

With the the first UN-recognised International Widows Day on Thursday 23rd June, Mia de Graaf investigates the invisible existence of the world's women in mourning (Thumbnail credit A widow from Vrindavan. Indian widows are conventionally expected to wear white.)

Stars on Broadway

A spectre is haunting Broadway. Bringing huge status and gargantuan salaries, but sometimes poor performances, it is easy to see the inclusion of film stars and veteran actors in Broadway and West End shows as merely a populist move

Future Sounds: Thundercat

As careers go, LA native Stephen Bruner has had a more varied one than most: he's been a touring session musician for Snoop Dogg and Eric Benet, had a stint in boy band No Curfew (apparently a hit in Germany), and played with hardcore legends Suicidal Tendencies (technically he still is a member) (Thumbnail credit Thundercat)
